title: Czech police throw stun grenades at England fans as 10 arrested in Prague
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

England supporters have been involved in violent clashes with police ahead of the Three Lions’ Euro 2020 qualifier against the Czech Republic.

The ugly scenes erupted shortly before 7pm local time when some travelling fans started hurling bottles at armed officers wearing riot gear.

A recorded warning was played in English before groups of officer advanced on the fans through a small archway in Prague’s Old Town throwing stun grenades.

About a dozen men were forced into a corner and made to lie face down, while another was seen being pinned to the floor nearby as officers secured the scene.

Until night fell, there had been little trouble in the city, with police involvement limited to telling fans to remove flags from buildings.

England fans clash with Czech riot police ahead of Euro qualifier. OCTOBER 11, 2019 (c) 2019 Reuters [SOCCER-EURO-CZE-ENG/REPORT] (STREAM-700-16X9-MP4) pic.twitter.com/MgSUUBomhh — chris and the Fippos (@dotfip) October 11, 2019

England fans in Prague ahead of the qualifying match with the Czech Republic (Picture: Getty Images)

Almost 3,800 Three Lions fans bought tickets for Friday night’s clash (Picture: Getty Images)

Travelling fans swarmed a square in the city’s Old Town (Picture: Getty Images)

Some were involved in violent clashes with police (Picture: Getty Images)

There had been little trouble in the city until night fell (Picture: Getty Images)

A fan is arrested by police before the match (Picture: Reuters)

So far 10 have been detained (Picture: Reuters)

More than a dozen fans were either forced to the floor or told to lie down (Picture: Reuters)

Czech police have so far arrested 10 England fans.

Hundreds of away supporters took over a small square, chanting and drinking.

One local resident fought back against the noise, producing a megaphone to protest from his second-floor window.

Almost 3,800 Three Lions fans bought tickets for Friday night’s clash although more are believed to have travelled.

Oh my days, what on earth is happening in Prague before the England football match tonight… pic.twitter.com/O6gp9jZVjC — Leek TV (@tv_leek) October 11, 2019

The late kick-off time of 8.45pm and the city’s party reputation led to fears of a repeat of ugly scenes witnessed on recent trips to Amsterdam, Dortmund and Porto.

The fixture also coincides with a national day of mourning for the country’s most famous singer, Karel Gott, who died last week, with ravelling fans asked to be respectful of mourners.
